courses.name: Conservation Studies
courses.description: A one-week field experience in natural resource management issues-soil and water conservation, air pollution, fish and wildlife habitat requirements, importance of forest ecosystems. Limited to high school students who have completed their junior year and taken the PSAT or equivalent.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Ecology and Conservation of Natural Resources
courses.description: Introduction to the principles of resource and conservation describing the foundation of the variety of natural resources and conservation practices used to protect and maintain these resources.

courses.name: Ecology and Renewable Resource Management
courses.description: Introduction to ecological principles and their relationship to resource use and management.

courses.name: Topics in Natural Resources - Biological/Physical/Mathematical
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Topics in Natural Resources - Social Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Outdoor Recreation Consortium
courses.description: Outdoor Recreation Consortium is a collaborative course taught by MU, North Carolina State University, Penn State University, East Carolina University, Texas A&M University and Western Illinois University. The course uses Great Smoky Mountains National Park as a case study for understanding the relationship between ecosystem management, natural resource management, tourism, and outdoor recreation. This course is based around a one week trip to the Smokies. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: NAT_R 1070 or P_R_TR 2111 or ENV_SC 1100 and permission of instructor

courses.name: Issues in Natural Resources and the Environment
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to ecological and environmental challenges in natural resource management in our rapidly changing world. Topical discussions will provide students with informed perspectives of several contemporary issues that affect the sustainability of our natural resources.
courses.recommendation: This course is recommended as an introductory course for non-science majors

courses.name: Topics in Natural Resources
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics.  Subjects may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Natural Resource Biometrics
courses.description: Sampling methods and analysis as applied to a variety of natural resources, including fisheries, range, recreation, forests, water and wildlife.

courses.name: Public Relations for Natural Resource Managers
courses.description: Introduction to the practical nature of public relations for those entering natural resources careers, emphasis on communication with target audiences through news media, publications and exhibits.

courses.name: Hydrologic Measurement Techniques
courses.description: Students will be introduced to field methods and tools used by water resource and environmental science professionals.  Students will sample and measure hydrologic and environmental variables, learn about data storage systems, and access and analyze data. Course may be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Hydrologic Measurement Techniques - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Students will be introduced to field methods and tools used by water resource and environmental science professionals.  Students will sample and measure hydrologic and environmental variables, learn about data storage systems, and access and analyze data. Course may be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Natural Resources
courses.description: Problems in Natural Resources

courses.name: Topics in Natural Resources
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics.  Subjects may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Foundations of Environmental Education
courses.description: (same as ENV_SC 4024; cross-leveled with NAT_R 7024). This course provides a theoretical foundation to environmental education (EE). The purpose of this course is to develop the knowledge and skills for developing quality, age-appropriate EE for students in both formal and non-formal education setting. The emphasis is on EE curriculum materials, resources, and programs that can be used with students in settings at classrooms, nature centers, museums, and parks. This course involves training in the Missouri Department of Conservation Discover Nature School educational materials, and in observing and teaching EE lessons in a local nature center. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010 or ENV_SC 1100 or NAT_R 1060 or NAT_R 1070 or NAT_R 2160 or Instructor's consent

courses.name: Hydrologic and Water Quality Modeling
courses.description: (same as ENV_SC 4320).  Introduction to models for simulating hydrologic and water quality processes. Emphasis is placed on watersheds to provide experience with the use of simulation models for natural resource decision making.

courses.name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NAT_R 7325). The course will cover basic theoretical and technical issues in GIS, discuss processing geographic information for research and application, emphasis on the nature of spatial information, data models, input, manipulation and storage, and spatial analytic techniques.
courses.prerequisites: NAT_R 1070 or GEOG 2840; NAT_R 1080 and NAT_R 1090; instructor's consent

courses.name: Natural Resource Policy/Administration
courses.description: Principles of policy formation and analysis; relationship of organizational goals to structure, planning and budgeting. Historical background of present natural resource policies; examines current policy issues.

courses.name: GIS Applications
courses.description: Introduces logical thinking and techniques in applying GIS to practical problems. Covers general GIS functionalities, Arc View Spatial Analyst including georeference, terrain analysis, hydrological analysis, grid, and remote sensing image processing.

courses.name: Landscape Ecology and GIS Analysis I
courses.description: (same as GEOG 4810). Examination of the landscape-scale approach to biodiversity, ecosystem dynamics, and habitat management. Particular emphasis on the use of Geographic Information Systems to analyze the spatial dimension of ecological patterns and processes.

courses.name: Natural Resources Internship
courses.description: Supervised professional experience with an approved public or private organization. May be repeated for credit. Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: School of Natural Resources majors only, instructor's consent

courses.name: Resource Practicum in Natural Resources
courses.description: Multidisciplinary planning of a natural resource management program.
courses.prerequisites: School of Natural Resources majors only and senior standing

courses.name: Topics in Natural Resources
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics.  Subjects may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Foundations of Environmental Education
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NAT_R 4024, ENV_SC 4024). This course provides a theoretical foundation to environmental education (EE). The purpose of this course is to develop the knowledge and skills for developing quality, age-appropriate EE for students in both formal and non-formal education setting. The emphasis is on EE curriculum materials, resources, and programs that can be used with students in settings at classrooms, nature centers, museums, and parks. This course involves training in the Missouri Department of Conservation Discover Nature School educational materials, and in observing and teaching EE lessons in a local nature center. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Hydrologic and Water Quality Modeling
courses.description: (same as ENV_SC 7320). Introduction to models for simulating hydrologic and water quality processes. Emphasis is placed on Missouri watersheds to provide experience with the use of simulation models for natural resource decision making.
courses.prerequisites: NAT_R 1080 and NAT_R  1090 and SOIL 2100 or equivalent

courses.name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems
courses.description: (cross-leveled with NAT_R 4325). The course will cover basic theoretical and technical issues in GIS, discuss processing geographic information for research and application, emphasis on the nature of spatial information, data models, input, manipulation and storage, and spatial analytic techniques.
courses.prerequisites: NAT_R 1070 or GEOG 2840; NAT_R 1080 and NAT_R 1090; instructor's consent

courses.name: Natural Resource Policy/Administration
courses.description: Principles of policy formation and analysis; relationship of organizational goals to structure, planning and budgeting. Historical background of present natural resource policies; examines current policy issues.

courses.name: GIS Applications
courses.description: Introduces logical thinking and techniques in applying GIS to practical problems. Cover general GIS functionalities, Arc View Spatial Analyst including georeference, terrain analysis, hydrological analysis, grid, and remote sensing image processing.
courses.prerequisites: GEOG 3040, NAT_R 1080 and NAT_R 1090, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Landscape Ecology and GIS Analysis I
courses.description: (same as GEOG 7810). Examination of the landscape-scale approach to biodiversity, ecosystem dynamics, and habitat management. Particular emphasis on the use of Geographic Information Systems to analyze the spatial dimension of ecological patterns and processes.

courses.name: Topics in Natural Resources
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics.  Subjects may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Masters Non-Thesis Research in Natural Resources
courses.description: Research credits associated with a non-thesis M.S. project.  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: restricted to Masters students in the School of Natural Resources

courses.name: Master Thesis Research in Natural Resources
courses.description: Research credits leading to M.Sc. thesis.  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to Masters students in the School of Natural Resources

courses.name: Hydrologic Measurement and Synthesis
courses.description: Students are introduced to methods fundamental to measuring hydrologic processes, and assessing physical data, including field measurement, and data logging and acquisition information systems.  Students will gain experience analyzing and synthesizing hydrologic data using tools commonly used by water resource professionals.  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100, STAT 2530, PHYSCS 1210.  If deficient in prerequisite courses, or unsure of qualification, contact instructor for consent

courses.name: Landscape Ecology and GIS Analysis II
courses.description: (same as GEOG 8815). Provide students with principles and applications of landscape ecology and firm understandings of spatial analysis techniques using GIS. Discuss metrics for spatial pattern and models for landscape-scale dynamics.
courses.prerequisites: NAT_R 4365; FOREST 4320 or equivalent; basic statistics; instructor's consent

courses.name: Applied Research Methodology
courses.description: Interrelated roles or logic, observation experiment in scientific method, research components, ethical aspects, scientific publication and communication, and research direction.

courses.name: Society and Ecosystems Research Seminar
courses.description: (same as AG_EC 8448 and RU_SOC 8448). This seminar, capstone for the Graduate Certificate Program in Society and Ecosystems, exposes students to interdisciplinary research on interactions between social, economic and ecological systems.

courses.name: Topics in Natural Resources
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics.  Subjects and topics may vary from semester to semester. Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent. Restricted to School of Natural Resources Graduate Students

courses.name: Graduate Seminar in Natural Resources
courses.description: Graduate seminar in Natural Resources.  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: restricted to PhD students in the School of Natural Resources

courses.name: Dissertation Research in Natural Resources
courses.description: Research leading to a dissertation and Ph.D. in the School of Natural Resources.  Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Restricted to PhD students in the School of Natural Resources

courses.name: Ecohydrology: Contemporary Topics
courses.description: A series of discussions centered on primary literature within disciplines relevant to the participants.  All Natural Resources disciplines are encouraged to participate (e.g., ecology, wildlife, fisheries, recreation/tourism, hydrology, atmospheric sciences, soils, etc.) with emphasis on interdisciplinary research (i.e. integrated natural, social and/or physical scientific research).  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.
